title: The Tragic Irony of Admiral Sakazuki's Name
summary: The name 'Sakazuki' refers to both the brotherhood ceremony and Admiral Akainu's real name, creating a cruel irony as Sakazuki (Akainu) kills Ace, breaking the bond formed through the sakazuki ceremony.
fullText: Admiral Akainu's true name is Sakazuki, which is the exact same word used for the traditional Japanese brotherhood ceremony where individuals form family-like bonds by exchanging sake cups. In Episode 496, Ace, Sabo, and Luffy perform this sakazuki ceremony to become sworn brothers. The tragic irony is that Admiral Sakazuki is directly responsible for killing Ace at Marineford, essentially ending the ASL (Ace-Sabo-Luffy) brotherhood. The man whose name means 'brotherhood ceremony' destroyed the brotherhood he's named after. This symbolism suggests Oda intentionally chose this name to highlight the inverse relationship - while the ceremony creates bonds, Admiral Sakazuki destroys them. Some fans believe this wasn't coincidental but rather a deliberate narrative choice to emphasize the tragedy of Ace's death and its impact on the brotherhood.
author: One Piece Fan Community

title: Sakazuki Paradoxically Reunited the Brothers
summary: By killing Ace, Admiral Sakazuki inadvertently cured Sabo's amnesia and reunited the three brothers in spirit, as the news article featuring Ace, Luffy, and Sakazuki's names triggered Sabo's memory recovery.
fullText: This theory posits that Admiral Sakazuki (Akainu), despite killing Ace and seemingly destroying the brotherhood, actually reunited the three brothers in a paradoxical way. When Ace died at Marineford, the news article about his death featured the names of both Ace and Luffy, along with Sakazuki's own name - the word for the brotherhood ceremony that had bonded them. This combination of his two brothers' names along with the word for their bonding ceremony appeared together in print, triggering the return of Sabo's memories that had been lost due to amnesia. Sabo himself stated that he felt Ace's spirit lift the fog in his mind. Now that Sabo has inherited Ace's will and the Mera Mera no Mi, the three brothers have been reunited in spirit - Ace lives on through Sabo. Ironically, this reunion only happened because Sakazuki killed Ace. The theory suggests Oda intended this as a complex narrative where the destroyer of their bond inadvertently facilitated their spiritual reunion, with Sakazuki's name serving as the key that unlocked Sabo's memories.
author: CBR Analysis

title: Sabo's Noble Background Foreshadowed His Revolutionary Role
summary: Sabo's rejection of his noble heritage and escape to Grey Terminal in Episode 496 foreshadows his future role as Chief of Staff of the Revolutionary Army, fighting against the World Government's class system.
fullText: This theory suggests that Sabo's backstory revealed in Episode 496 deliberately foreshadows his future as the Revolutionary Army's Chief of Staff. As a child, Sabo rejected the oppressive noble system of Goa Kingdom, choosing freedom in Grey Terminal over wealth and status in High Town. His father Outlook III prioritized social advancement over his son's happiness, and the kingdom itself represented extreme class inequality - proclaimed 'the most beautiful kingdom in East Blue' while hiding its garbage and poor citizens in Grey Terminal. Sabo's experiences with this system and his conscious rejection of nobility perfectly align with the Revolutionary Army's mission to overthrow oppressive governments and class systems. The theory proposes that Oda planted these seeds in the Post-War Arc flashbacks to make Sabo's later reveal as Dragon's right-hand man feel natural and earned. Sabo didn't randomly join the Revolutionary Army - his entire childhood was preparation for understanding and fighting against systemic inequality. His unique perspective as someone who experienced both sides of the class divide makes him the perfect revolutionary leader.
author: One Piece Theory Community

title: Ace's Vow Was Tragically Fulfilled
summary: Ace's declaration in Episode 496 that he would become so famous 'everyone will know my name' was tragically fulfilled through his death at Marineford, not through his pirate achievements as he intended.
fullText: In Episode 496, after the sakazuki ceremony, Ace declares to his brothers: 'I'll become such a pirate that everyone will know my name!' This moment is seen by many fans as tragic foreshadowing. Ace's vow does come true - everyone in the world does learn his name - but not in the way he hoped. Rather than achieving fame through great pirate accomplishments, Ace becomes world-famous through his public execution at Marineford and his death saving Luffy from Admiral Sakazuki. The entire world watched the war, and the news of the execution of Gold Roger's son spread globally. Ace's name became legendary, but at the cost of his life. This theory suggests Oda intentionally wrote this scene to create dramatic irony - giving Ace the fame he desired while taking everything else. It also adds emotional weight to the brotherhood scenes, as viewers watching these flashbacks after Marineford know that Ace's dream came true in the cruelest way possible. The theory is supported by similar instances in One Piece where characters' dreams come true but with unexpected or tragic twists.
author: One Piece Analysis Community
